title: How to plan my trip to Canary Islands - Quora

response.answer_text: You have to decide which island you want to go to. Tenerife, followed by Gran Canaria, have the most to do. These are the islands with a TON of night life, restaurants, clubs, etc. You won’t usually get bored at all. If you want an adult all-inclusive and fantastic beaches, then you want Fuertaventura followed by Lanzarote. If you’re into doing things that are a bit off the beaten path, then maybe La Palma, La Gomera or El Hierro are for you. These last three islands aren’t the most touristy places, but offer really great hiking and camping. They’re really popular with people who don’t want to sit around on a beach. After that, you need to select where you want to stay. If you’re staying on Fuertaventura or Lanzarote, you’re almost certainly going to be by a beach and that’ll be that. If you’re staying on El Hierro, La Gomera or La Palma, you may not be in a beach town, but given the size of the islands, it won’t matter. You’ll be so close to the ocean that you will get there in no time (though the coasts will be rocky). In any case, these islands are conducive to renting a car and driving around to see them. Other than Fuerteventura, the other islands can be circumnavigated in a few hours, but Fuert will gobble up a whole day (not a bad thing!). The two places where you have to put some thought into it will be Gran Canaria or Tenerife. Because they’re so big and mountainous, you’re going to get some climate variations. Tenerife has THE most variation in climate. The north is lush and green (windward) and generally a bit cooler (but shouldn’t be presumed as “cold” — it’s a warm, sunny island, not Ireland). The southwest is hot and dry (and the most touristy part). The southeast is a bit drier as well though not as much as the southwest part. Gran Canaria is mostly dry and sunny, though the northern half is a bit wetter and a bit greener. If you want really great beaches but also access to a larger island with great night life, then Gran Canaria will probably be a superior choice. The beaches beat Tenerife. While Tenerife does have some nice beaches, I must confess, they’re nothing compared to Lanzarote or Fuertaventura. No matter what, these aren’t huge islands and you can rent a car and really get to see a lot of the island in a few days of exploring. The most difficult part is choosing. After that, you book your hotel, accept the fact that you’re going to just have to get lost and then find your way around. That’s the best part.
